p.s: Description of Mycobacterium mageritense sp. nov.
Mycobacterium mageritense (ma.ge.ri.ten'se. L. neut. adj. mageritense, pertaining to Magerit, old [first] Arabic name of Madrid, the source of most of the isolates)
Colonies on Lowenstein-Jensen medium are smooth, mucoid, and nonphotochromogenic.
Growth occurs at 22, 30, 37, and 45°C; optimum growth occurs at 30 and 37°C.
M. mageritense is resistant in vitro to hydrazide, cycloserine, capreomycin, pyrazinamide, thiosemicarbazone, and thiophen- 2-carboxylic acid hydrazide.
Negative for Tween hydrolysis and for production of thermostable catalase.
Positive for arylsulfatase activity at 3 days, nicotinamidase and pyrazinamidase activities, and use of mannitol as a sole carbon source.
Variable in tests for nitrate reductase, several amidases, utilization of citrate and inositol as sole carbon sources, and iron uptake.

The results of DNA analyses (DNA-DNA hybridization, RFLP analysis of 16s rRNA genes, PCR-RFLP analysis of the hsp65 gene, sequences of sod4 and 16s rRNA genes) show that M. mageritense is a distinct genomic species that is closely related to M. fortuitum and M. peregrinum at the DNA homology level.
The 16s rRNA and sod4 gene sequences of M. mageritense are unique.
Type strain 938 was isolated from human sputum; a culture of this strain has been deposited in the Collection de Bacteries de L'Institut Pasteur as strain CIP 104973.
